column4: I am trying to mount an old ubuntu install as a secondary drive in a new machine, so I can pull data off it.
I think /dev/hdc is the old ubuntu install, it appears to be an LVM parittion.
Do I need to do osmething funky to mount it?
what problem are you having with it?
Well, given the paste, what -t arg do I use with mount?
you can just guess a type, or use file -s /dev/hdc1

Okay, so /dev/hdc1 mounts ifne as ext3, but that's grub, vm, etc.  hdec2 is the boot partition so that doesn't buy me much.  sudo file -s /dev/hdc5 gets me: /dev/hdc5: LVM2 (Linux Logical Volume Manager) , UUID: r2qPJg6voPhTQpF5MiN2ZUvEHUiI4AV
So... how do I mount that?
I guess more importantly, what are the odds I'll be able to mount that on this machien (centos 5.2)?
I never used lvm, look at http://www.brandonhutchinson.com/Mounting_a_Linux_LVM_volume.html
I can't get past the second command in there, it says "mount /dev/hda /tmp/mnt" and doesn't specify a -t, when I leave out -t mount comiplains.
apparently you need to use the commands 'pvs' and 'lvdisplay' to see the names of the volumes
